newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia holds Singaporeans after drugs found.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia holds Singaporeans after drugs found.

text.p: Indonesian customs officials have detained two Singaporean traders after 16,527 Ecstasy pills were discovered at Jakarta's international airport, a customs official said on Monday.
"The pills were wrapped in packets of M&Ms (multi-coloured chocolate sweets)," Nifsu Chasbullah, head of customs and excise at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport, told Reuters by telephone.
Chasbullah said the two Singaporeans, whose names were not released, had travelled to Indonesia from Amsterdam via Hong Kong on a Cathay Pacific flight which landed on Sunday morning.

"Customs officers became suspicious after the baggage of the two men was X-rayed," he said, adding there was a strong suspicion the two men were working together as the pills were wrapped in an identical fashion.
There was no immediate estimate of the street value of the drugs. He said the men were due to be handed over to police in metropolitan Jakarta later on Monday.
Earlier this month, two other Singaporeans were caught at the same airport allegedly trying to smuggle 70,431 Ecstasy pills estimated to be worth $1.8 million in the largest single haul in Indonesia.
At the time, customs officials said they had seized 239,048 Ecstasy pills since March this year.
Ecstasy has gained widespread popularity in Indonesia's cities in recent years and the government has recently legislated to increase penalties for trafficking in and using it.
